item.title: Comment on How economists think about victims of natural disasters by mkt42
item.description:
Most of these low-lying barrier islands should not have permanent structures built on them in the first place.

But given that people are currently living there, if a disaster strikes we don't want to leave them high and dry (nor under water).

But what we can say is this: if your house is in an overly high-risk flood zone, you can put in an insurance claim and get reimbursed for your loss and rebuild your house -- as long as you don't rebuild it in a forbidden zone.

No one gets wiped out financially (if they are insured), and in the long run the intruding overly risky houses go away. And the barrier islands are returned to their natural state, as well as their natural function of occasionally flooding and moving and appearing and disappearing.
